dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) This is the story of my older brother's strange criminal behavior and disappearance. We who loved him no longer speak of Wade. It's as if he never existed. By telling his story like this, as his brother, I separate myself from his family and those who loved him. Everything of importance -- that is, everything that gives rise to the telling of this story -- occurred during a single deer-hunting season in a small town in upstate New Hampshire where Wade was raised and so was I. One night something changed and my relation to Wade's story was different from what it had been since childhood. I mark this change by Wade's tone of voice during a phone call two nights after Halloween. Something I had not heard before. Let us imagine that around eight o'clock on Halloween Eve, speeding past Toby's, Route 29, comes a pale green eight-year-old Ford Fairlane with a police bubble on top. A square-faced man wearing a trooper's cap is driving the vehicle. Beside him sits a child, a little girl with a plastic tiger mask covering her face. The man is driving fast --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ./EXT. POLICE CAR - NIGHT WADE WHITEHOUSE, driving, sits beside JILL, his daughter, ten years-old, wearing a black-and-yellow tiger plastic mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade watches boys in the headlights, lights cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade grimaces, holds his jaw. The Fairlane swerves around broken pumpkins under a caution light.

direction.raw_text: Wade looks at her, wanting to lift her mask, see her face.

direction.raw_text: On stage, LaRiviere arranges the contest winners. A fairy godmother with a wand beams while, nearby, a hobo writhes in his mother's grip -- a hard loser. Wade looks for Jill, first among the winners, then among the losers; she's nowhere to be found. He heads toward a hall leading to the restrooms. Jill stands alone in the corner next to the pay phone, tiny, forlorn. Wade realizes at once he was wrong to leave her before she had found a friend.

dialogue.raw_text: Some party, huh? Sorry I lost sight of you. I had to step outside for a smoke. You find anybody you know here? There must be some kids you used to know from school. You want to go tomorrow? See your old teachers? Be more fun than hanging out with me all day.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.

direction.raw_text: . WADE'S TRAILER HOME - DAWN Pre-dawn light silhouettes a dozen weather-beaten mobile homes set off Route 29. Snow continues to fall. A sheet of white stretches down Parker mountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: :40. A clock radio pierces the silence with classic rock. Wade Whitehouse rolls over, runs his tongue across mossy teeth, shuts off the music. He looks out the window, grunts: "Shit!" He steps over to the phone by the frayed plaid couch, dials. Wade's trailer is surprisingly neat, considering its owner smokes too much, drinks too much, eats take-out and rarely cleans up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Lugene? Wade. Hoya doin? (fumbles for cigarette) Look, I was wondering, with the snow and all, if you got school today? (lights cigarette) How the hell do I know? You're the principal. All I'm supposed to do is direct traffic from 7:30 to 8:30. (listens) Yeah, okay, I'm sorry -- I only just now saw it was snowing, that's all. My whole day is fucked. I gotta plow all day. If I don't get over to LaRiviere's early enough, I'm stuck with the grader. I was just hoping you'd have called school off. (beat) You check the weather bureau? (acquiesces) Okay, I hear you. I'll be over in a bit. (hangs up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jack Hewitt's 4x4 passes Wade's trailer, continues up 29. Tire chains splice the path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack behind the wheel. Beside him EVAN TWOMBLEY, 60, fleshy, Irish, wearing brand new scarlet wool pants, jacket and cap. He feeds on the misfortunes of others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hewitt looks at Twombley's rifle: a Winchester M-94 pump- action, custom carved stock and not a scratch on it. Never fired, at least not by Twombley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pickup disappears behind a curve of pine and spruce trees.

dialogue.raw_text: It's not enough snow, not for tracking the bastards. No advantage there, kid.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Mr. Twombley, I know where those suckers are. Rain or shine, snow or no snow. I know deer. We'll kill us a buck today. Guaranteed. Before ten.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep. Right about now the does are holing up in the brush piles. The bucks are right behind them and we're right behind the bucks. (gestures to gun rack) This gun gets fired before ten o'clock. Whether it kills a deer or not is more less up to you. I'll put you inside 30, 35 yards of a buck the first four hours of the season. That's what you're paying me for, ain't it?

dialogue.raw_text: Mmm.

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Wonderful!

direction.raw_text: Wade Whitehouse, wearing a reflective vest, waves a district school bus into the parking lot. Noisy, jostling grade schoolers emerge from the bus. Jill's former classmates. Straight as a statue, Wade holds back traffic. Cars and trucks are backed up on the unplowed road. Horns honk and bleat; a woman's voice yells, "Whitehouse, we 'ain't got all day!" Wade, daydreaming, seems oblivious to the commotion. Oblivious -- or just plum contrary. A shiny black BMW approaches, speeding, passing traffic on the shoulder. A man and a woman in a fur coat sit in front, two children in back. Whitehouse waves for it to stop. The BMW accelerates through the intersection, ignoring Wade and the traffic. It whizzes past, spinning Wade, and is quickly up the road, spewing ice and exhaust. Wade slips to one knee. Honking ensues; every car goes where it wishes. Wade, brushing off snow, follows the last bus as it pulls in. LUGENE BROOKS, 60, school principal, rushes over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade sets his face, thinking.

Except it's been out back two months and it's snowed and rained and froze so now the wood's all iced in. He takes the boys. He was drunk, of course.

direction.raw_text: . 29 - NIGHT Wade, driving Gordon's 4x4 with running lights and roll bar, takes 29 toward Pop's farm. A pickup passes him: Jack Hewitt's burgundy Ford. Wade stops. Jack turns up Parker Mountain -- the road to the accident scene. Something's up. Wade turns and follows. Jack's fresh tracks lead the way. Hewitt is driving fast. Wade keeps up. Jack, far ahead, approaches the accident scene. Stops. Night has fallen. Wade comes over a low rise, spots Jack's pickup. He kills the lights, parks to block Jack's exit. Silence. Footsteps in the snow. Wade watches, listens. What's he doing? Looking for evidence? The burgundy pickup engine suddenly ROARS -- Jack's back and at the wheel -- the tires squeal, spit snow as he spins past Wade. Wade starts his engine, gives pursuit. The pickups gun their engines, bumper to bumper, down mountain roads, lumber roads, rocky trails. Wild headlamps their only guide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trail turns sharply past a shallow beaver pond -- too sharply for Jack. He crashes through a stand of skinny birches straight out onto the pond. The pickup's momentum carries it across the pond. Wade drops into first gear, follows, his headlights reflecting ice. He drives directly to Jack, bumper to bumper, headlight to headlight. Jack sticks his head out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade doesn't budge. Jack backs away; Wade inches forward. Hewitt's trapped. Trees behind him. Neither truck has traction on ice. Jack steps out, swinging his fists wildly. Wade gets out. Jacks grabs his rifle, points it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade backs off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack gets back in his pickup, maneuvers it slowly around the Dodge, crosses the ice and is gone. Wade stands in darkness. The only sound his idling truck, the wind. Then a third sound -- the snap of ice. Ice cracks ripple from the middle of the pond. Ice planes tip around the truck. LaRiviere's snazzy Dodge slips, descends, disappears. Headlights glow under water, then go out. "Our Business Is Going In The Hole." Wade, alone in darkness, plops into the water, paddles to shore. Freezing, he finds Jack's tire tracks in the snow. He bangs his jaw.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I heard you talking. You got fired this morning, didn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, that's temporary, believe me. There's so much shit gonna hit the fan the next few days, my getting fired by LaRiviere and Merritt won't matter a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get another job. People are going to need me. After this is over, they'll make me into a Goddamned hero. You wait: you'll see, I'll deliver. I'll be the best father who ever lived. You need me, even Pop, for Christ's sake, he needs me. This town needs me. Maybe now they think they can send me howling into a corner like a kicked dog, but my God, it'll be different soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave the bottle out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) You will say I should have known terrible things were about to happen, and perhaps I should have. But even so, what could I have done by then? Wade never went inside. He lived almost wholly out there on his skin, with no interior space to retreat to, even in a crisis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wade spits blood into the snow as he grabs a gallon can of gasoline from under the porch. He crosses to the barn, prepares to pour the gas into the beat-up red truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade's Ford pickup passes J. Battle Hand's office, keeps going. Grass peeks through the snow at this lower altitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade parks the truck, walks past leafless bushes to a charcoal- gray split-level with pink shutters. He pushes the door bell; the first notes of "Frere Jacques" play. Lillian opens the door; Jill's footsteps approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill returns, wearing parka and boots, heads out with her father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade and Jill approach the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade opens the truck door. Jill climbs in with her overnight bag, looks back to the door where Lillian watches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait there. She'll be right out. (looks back) Is there snow on the ground up in Lawford?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, lots.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Jill) See. Get your boots.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going back inside) Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have her back tomorrow night by six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No problem. Look, I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make me sick. I can't believe you've sunk so low.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Low as what? What have I done? It's bad to want to see your own daughter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I'm talking about. For what you're doing to me and to the child you say you love so much. Love. You won't get away with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye, honey! Call me tonight if you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are we going in this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. My car's in the shop. This'll be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's pretty old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It belongs to Pop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grandpa. My father. It's his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Ford heads north.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop for a light. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pause. Wade looks over at Jill and realizes she is crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shoves her clenched fists hard against her legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill looks away. Wade pulls a six-pack from under the seat, pulls off a beer, takes a swig.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (winking) How about a Big Mac?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mommy won't let me eat fast food. You know that. It's bad for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, we can always sneak a Big Mac. And a cherry turnover. Your favorite. What do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't have nothing, Jill. We need lunch. Mr. Pizza?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same thing, Daddy. Mommy says -- WADE I know what Mommy says. I'm in charge today, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. So we'll get what you want. What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, I guess. I guess I can wait till we get home. Maybe we'll stop by Wickham's for a hamburger when we get to Lawford. That suit you? You always like Wickham's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking ahead) Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Jesus, Jill, I'm sorry. What's the matter, honey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't cry. Please, honey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (regains composure) What are you sorry for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. For the food business. I guess. I just thought, you know, we'd sneak a Big Mac on Mommy, like we used to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quick) You can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) That's illegal, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a policeman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. Not anymore. I'm nothing anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wade and Jill enter Wickham's, crowded with out-of-state hunters at the end of the deer season.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade, flaring, reaches across the counter and grabs Nick by the shirtfront! Nick's arm knocks over a cup of coffee. The diner goes silent. Hunters look up. Jill's face is white; she starts to cry. Wade looks over -- it takes him a moment to react -- bends down, comforting her. He wipes her nose with a napkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They head for the door. Nick eases over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade takes Jill's hand, exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jillie, you want a cheese grilled sandwich?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's called a grilled cheese sandwich, you dub.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jill, please, it's alright. Nothing happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rigid) Okay, let's go home, then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delicate) Wade, I got a message for you. (Wade turns) Jack Hewitt, he's looking for you. Wants you to clear your stuff out of his office in Town Hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His office. You mean my old office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I guess -- that's what he said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He got his deer yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he's out now. Somewhere on the mountain. I'd stay away from him if I were you. He's real pissed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jill waits in the old red truck parked outside. Wade emerges with cardboard boxes of office miscellany, rifles laid across top. He shoves the boxes and guns into the back of the pickup, gets in and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade and Jill pull up the drive, past Margie's car, into the barn. Her trunk and two side doors are open. Margie comes out back with a battered suitcase, goes to her car. She's leaving. A plastic bag of clothes sits in the trunk. Wade and Jill get out, approach:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jill, suitcase in hand, looking pathetic, tries to smile. A sadness passes over Wade's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Margie, watching him, quivers, starts to cry. She drops her suitcase, out of nowhere bawling like a baby. Wade goes over, puts his arms around her, pats her back. His face is racked. He, too, seems about to cry -- if he could. In his arms Margie feels trapped, overwhelmed by Wade's circumstances and terrible sadness. She pushes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She struggles in Wade's grasp. Jill, frightened, wildly hits him from behind:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade moves back like a bear, covering his face and arms. Jill, near hysterical, keeps after him, arms and fists flying. Wade stumbles backwards into the snow. Jill still swings. Margie dashes to intervene as Wade swings his arms wide. Jill flies into Marg. Her nose is bleeding. Wade's caught her across the mouth and nose. She takes cover behind Margie, crying. Margie and Jill stand side by side, saying nothing. Wade looks up stunned, as if hit by a rock. Marg slowly backs away, her arms behind her holding Jill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marg eases Jill into the front seat, closes the door, edges around the car slamming the trunk and gets into the driver's seat. Wade stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes the front door, starts the car. She backs out the drive. In her rear view mirror she sees the image of Wade receding, standing frozen, staring down at the snow. Pop emerges from the house, looks at his son, grinning. Wade looks at his old man, that dumb devilish grin plastered on his father's face. Glen Whitehouse holds an empty whiskey bottle like a pistol. Hunters' gunshots echo in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pop holds up the bottle, pretends to fire it at Wade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade waves his old man off, trudges toward the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade walks from the glistening snow into the dark barn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Going somewhere, Margie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just cleaning out some of this stuff that's built up. For the rummage sale. And some things for the cleaners. And the laundromat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't lie to me. You're leaving me, I can see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be silly. Hi, Jill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt) Marg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying) Leave me alone! Leave me alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave her alone! Leave her alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Jill) Get in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go home. Will you take me home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Satanic delight) You! By Christ, you -- I know you. (points bottle) Yeah, you goddamn sonofabitch, I know you. You're a goddamn fucking piece of my heart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dead) You don't know me. You don't know me! (beat) So fuck you. Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah-nah-naw! You done done finally done it! Like a man done it. Done it right. I love you, you mean sonofabitch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love! What the fuck do you know about love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Love! I'm made of love!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call it what you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything you know is from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bang!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where the Christ you going? You sonofabitch, you leave my fucking truck where it is! I need... Give me the Goddamn keys! I need to get me to town!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crawl!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing in the fucking house to drink. Not a fucking thing. My house, my money, my truck -- stolen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know you. My goddamn father and I don't know you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wade unloads the cardboard boxes filled with his office belongings from the back of the truck and sets them on the ground. He gathers up his rifles. Suddenly! A whiskey bottle SLAMS against the back of his head. He drops to his knees, the guns scatter. He looks up with child's fear and guilt at his father. Glen Whitehouse hovers over him, huge and ferocious: a colossus, lifting the bottle like a jawbone. Wade cringes, scrambles for the dropped rifle. He grabs it by the barrel and, twisting around, swings it in a slow motion arc, smashing the edge of the wood stock against his father's head. A cold hard CRACK of bone. Glen Whitehouse -- shriveled again, no longer mythic -- flies back like a stuffed dummy. He collapses beside the empty C.C. bottle. Wade, bleeding from the head, stands, staggers off Pop's inert body, aims his rifle at the old man's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade bolts the rifle, flicks off the safety, fires -- a loud CLICK. The gun's empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kneels down, lovingly touches the old man's face, caresses his lips, cheeks, nose, brows, smoothes back his stiff gray hair. Pop's eyes are clouded. Blood suddenly drips from his ear to the ground. Wade rests the rifle against the truck. He bends over, slips his hands under his father's body, lifts him up. He carries Pop over to the workbench, lays him out. Groping beneath the bench, Wade finds the kerosene lamp. He unscrews it, pours kerosene the length of Pop's body. Wade takes out his cigarette lighter, ignites it, holds it for a moment, places it to Glen Whitehouse. Fire spreads the length of Pop's body, bursting like a shroud of yellow flame. The oil-stained bench crackles; flames shoot up the old weathered wall. Burning flesh and heat drive Wade backwards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know you now. I love you too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Joke. You scared me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wade stands in snow and sunlight. The entire barn is engulfed in flames. Black smoke billows through the clear winter sky. Inside Glen Whitehouse, a pyre, burns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The historical facts are known by everyone -- all of Lawford, all of New Hampshire, some of Massachusetts. Facts do not make history. Our stories, Wade's and mine, describe the lives of boys and men for thousands of years, boys who were beaten by their fathers, whose capacity for love and trust was crippled almost at birth and whose best hope, if any, for connection with other human beings lay in an elegiac detachment, as if life were over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pop's red truck is parked behind Jack Hewitt's 4x4 on a snow- banked road. Wade, hunting rifle pointed up, traces Jack's footsteps down the slope of the mountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wade spots Jack poised in a spruce grove, watching for deer. Wade bolts his rifle, releases the safety, aims and FIRES. Jack, hit in the chest, falls bleeding between trees. Blood stains the snow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It's how we keep from destroying in turn our own children and terrorizing the women who have the misfortune to love us; how we absent ourselves from the tradition of male violence; how we decline the seduction of revenge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Jack's truck turned up three days later in a shopping mall in Toronto. Even without the footprints, the bullet, Wade's utter disappearance seemed evidence enough of his guilt.
dialogue.name: dialogue
